item.title: Ex-BioWare Dev Disputes The Idea That It Shouldn‚Äôt Have Made Anthem
item.content:encoded:
Anthem‚Äôs servers have been shut down for a week now, marking the end of a pretty tragic chapter in developer BioWare‚Äôs history. The live-service looter shooter‚Äôs crash and burn reportedly nudged publisher EA to let the studio strip out the reported multiplayer elements from the game that would go on to become Dragon Age: The Veilguard, which signaled to some that the studio was ‚Äúreturning‚Äù to its roots. However, as Anthem has been dropped down into an abyss, ex-BioWare producer Mark Darrah is disputing the notion that the game was that far out of left field for the studio.

In an interview with YouTuber Destin Legarie, Darrah talked at length about the life and death of Anthem, and in the closing minutes, Legarie asks if there‚Äôs anything Darrah wants to ‚Äúset the record straight‚Äù on regarding the game. Darrah replies that while many people want to point fingers solely at EA for mandating that the historically single-player RPG studio shift into making an ill-advised cooperative loot shooter, it wasn‚Äôt ‚Äúall their fault.‚Äù He also said that, at the time, the prospect of making Anthem seemed like just the latest evolution for a studio that had evolved many times before, so he says he is less swayed by arguments stating that the company shouldn‚Äôt have even tried.

‚ÄúMy feeling is that BioWare has always been changing,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI mean, by that argument, we should never have made Neverwinter Nights because we were a 2D RPG maker. We should never have made Mass Effect because we were a tactical RPG maker, not an action RPG maker. So I don‚Äôt know that that argument holds a lot of weight for me. To me, it‚Äôs like, yeah, your studios evolve, and they try new things, and was Anthem too big of a reach? Yeah, for sure. But could you tell at the time? I don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt know that you could.‚Äù

In a perfect world, developers would be able to make mistakes like Anthem without risking going under, but reports about Anthem‚Äôs development indicate that it did some seismic damage to BioWare internally that it‚Äôs still recovering from. The company was downsized last year as a small team works on the next Mass Effect game. We‚Äôll see if it‚Äôs enough to get the studio back on track after a decade of strife.

item.title: Life Is Strange: Reunion Leaks Early, Coming Sooner Than We Thought
item.content:encoded:
The rumors were true. Life Is Strange: Reunion is coming, and it‚Äôs bringing Chloe Price back into the fold after 2024‚Äôs Double Exposure hinted at her return. Perhaps most surprisingly, however, it‚Äôs coming out in just two months.

The official announcement is set to go live at 1 p.m. Eastern, but Xbox Wire posted its announcement blog a bit early. Reunion will star both Max Caulfield and Chloe as co-protagonists, with both having different gameplay mechanics. Max is able to rewind time as she did in the first Life Is Strange, while Chloe will use her argumentative ‚ÄúBacktalk‚Äù mechanic from the prequel Before the Storm.

The big question is how Chloe is able to return despite her possibly dying at the end of the original Life Is Strange, a choice that Double Exposure made a point to import. Based on this line in the blog post, it seems like it may be as a result of the timeline jumping Max did in Double Exposure, though I expect the minutiae of this to be affected by which choice you made way back in 2015.

Chloe‚Äôs return may be due to Max‚Äôs power, in particular, the power Max gained in Life is Strange: Double Exposure to Shift between parallel timelines ‚Äî a power Max subsequently lost when she merged those timelines back together and recovered her ability to Rewind.

Whatever the case, it does seem like Reunion is not undoing either choice, as the blog says ‚ÄúWhether Chloe lived or died in Arcadia Bay, and whether she and Max were friends or lovers ‚Äî these choices are key not just to the past you‚Äôll confirm as you play, but to the future you‚Äôll fight for the chance to build.‚Äù So I will hold judgement for the time being, and I won‚Äôt have to wait long, as Reunion is coming to PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X/S on March 27.

Update: 1/20/26, 1:00 p.m. ET: Alright now that the actual announcement livestream is up, we know how the game will handle both endings.

How Reunion handles both Life Is Strange endings

As expected, Max‚Äôs merging of the timelines at the end of Double Exposure is at the heart of Chloe‚Äôs appearance. Rhianna DeVries, who voiced the character in Before the Storm, is reprising the role in Reunion, and the version of her we meet seems to have contradictory memories from both timelines. Though where she truly originates from will seemingly be affected by the decision you made at the end of Life Is Strange. You can see an example of two exchanges between Max and Chloe that play out differently depending on which choice you made at the 37-minute mark of the reveal stream above.

item.title: The Borderlands 4 Switch 2 Port Might Not Be Missing For Much Longer
item.content:encoded:
Nintendo presidents past and present are in the news this week. One of 2025‚Äôs biggest blockbusters might finally have a Switch 2 release date again. And if you bought Oblivion Remastered and barely played it, you‚Äôre hardly alone. It‚Äôs the latest edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news, rumors, and culture.

It‚Äôs currently Backlog Week around these parts. I spent the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday weekend playing a ridiculous amount of Dome Keeper with my kids. It came to Game Pass recently and is a clever little roguelite tower defense game that‚Äôs surprisingly hard to put down. The winter doldrums are ending this week, though. Lots of fresh 2026 releases are just around the corner.

Borderlands 4 seems slated to finally release on Switch 2 in February

A store listing on Portuguese site GamingReplay (via TheGamer) states a release date of February 27, 2026 for the sci-fi sequel. That‚Äôs a Thursday, so that tracks. It also puts it after a potential February Nintendo Direct to perhaps remind everyone it‚Äôs still coming. The port was indefinitely delayed last fall as Gearbox Entertainment addressed performance issues with the PC version of the loot shooter.

It‚Äôs a good thing The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered didn‚Äôt charge by gameplay minute actually completed

Alinea Analytics‚Äô Rhys Elliot recently pointed out (via FRVR) that while Oblivion Remastered sold over 1 million copies on PS5, about half of those buyers played less than 15 hours of the sprawling RPG. The Steam data is similarly stark. Per TheGamer, only 55 percent of PC players got the game‚Äôs first story quest achievement, only 11 percent entered the Shivering Isles, and only 7.5 percent completed the main quest.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 just had its best sales month in over 8 years

Sales for both BG3 and D:OS 2 have been incredible since the announcement of Divinity.

D:OS 2 really surprised us by having its best month since release in 2017. Wish I‚Äôd removed the squirrel in time üôÇ https://t.co/fXTEUtuS7r

‚Äî Swen Vincke @where? (@LarAtLarian) January 20, 2026

The announcement of Divinity in December spurred players to return to both Baldur‚Äôs Gate 3 and the 2017 RPG. No doubt part of that was a big Switch 2 upgrade and a half-off sale.

World of Warcraft veteran will work on Riot‚Äôs MMO

Blizzard producer Raymond Bartos has joined Riot Games (via MassivelyOP). ‚ÄúI‚Äôm incredibly excited to be joining Riot on the MMO team!!!‚Äù he posted. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm deeply grateful for the opportunity to join such an inspiring group of people, and I can‚Äôt wait to get started ‚Äî showing up every day to provide value for Riot gamers and help deliver an MMO experience players truly enjoy.‚Äù He‚Äôll be back with past collaborator Orlando Salvatore and said he thinks the team will be ‚Äúmoving fast on day one.‚Äù

New Fable art work has surfaced

Fable | Concept Arthttps://t.co/OuQzqybQut pic.twitter.com/ci23N0n0xW

‚Äî Klobrille (@klobrille) January 20, 2026

It looks very neat (via MP1st). Will it be a modern open-world RPG? Who knows. But hopefully at least some of the game‚Äôs scenes can match the promise of its concept art. Will it actually come out in 2026? I‚Äôm still skeptical.

A message from Nintendo of America‚Äôs new leader

Recently promoted veteran Devon Pritchard appeared in a video at the New York Game Awards to encourage the next generation of creators (via VGC). ‚ÄúAnd remember, like any good video game character, you‚Äôre on an adventure, and every step you take matters,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThere are some gnarly bosses, sure, but also many good friends along the way who will support you and powerful rewards for those who persevere. So, keep believing, keep playing, and know that you truly belong in this game.‚Äù

Doug Bowser joins Hasbro‚Äôs Board of Directors

The ex-Nintendo of America president will now be part of the corporate governance team overseeing the owner of Magic: The Gathering, Dungeons & Dragons, Transformers, and more. Is this the first step toward Nintendo doing a Universes Beyond MTG set? Probably not but I would, against my better judgement, buy the hell out of one.

item.title: Every Old Game Deserves A 60FPS Update
item.content:encoded:
Returning to old games isn‚Äôt always easy. Depending on how old the game is, you might run into various problems, including unusual controls or compatibility issues. Another common point of friction you might encounter is an older game running poorly. This can make it a slog to replay some of the modern classics, even if they‚Äôre just a decade or so old. So I‚Äôm happy to see Ubisoft going back and updating performance in games like Far Cry Primal and Assassin‚Äôs Creed Unity.

Over the weekend, Ubisoft announced that Far Cry 3 Classic is getting an update on January 21 that will let it run at a smoother, higher 60FPS on PS5 and Xbox Series X/S. It‚Äôs a free patch and, assuming nothing breaks, it should just work once players have updated the remastered version of the tropical shooter. Later, on January 19, Ubisoft announced that Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon Classic Edition is also getting a 60FPS patch on PS5 and Xbox Series X/S. And then, on Tuesday, Ubisoft revealed that Far Cry Primal, the primitive-era caveman spin-off, is getting a 60FPS patch for those same platforms. Both of these are landing on January 21, too.

Updating three older PS4-era games for free to add in performance improvements on newer consoles is cool enough. But Ubisoft has actually been doing this for a bit now. In December 2025, Ubisoft updated the OG Division on PS5 to unlock 60FPS. Last year, Ubisoft updated Far Cry 4 for current-gen machines, and now it runs like butter at 60FPS. In 2024, Assassin‚Äôs Creed Syndicate got a nifty 60FPS patch for free as well. And the year before that, Far Cry 5 got a 60FPS patch for Xbox Series X/S and PS5.

Ubisoft doesn‚Äôt have to do this. A lot of publishers don‚Äôt do this, which you can tell by all the people in the comments below Ubisoft‚Äôs announcements begging for similar updates to other games from other companies. And look, sometimes, it‚Äôs not an option. Some games are built around 30FPS and updating them is very tricky or too resource intensive. It‚Äôs not impossible, though. Just look at fan updates to Bloodborne.

Still, if you can update an older game without too much trouble to get it running at 60FPS or higher, I think it‚Äôs a smart move. From a business point of view, Ubisoft can now continue to market these older games and likely sell new copies. And with a Far Cry TV show in the works at FX, Ubisoft has already ensured that if the show is a hit, people coming back to the older games it was inspired by will find a 60FPS experience that matches many of today‚Äôs games.

Meanwhile, for me, these updates make it more likely that I‚Äôll return to one of these classic Ubisoft games in the future if I feel the urge to stab people in the throat. Which franchise am I talking about? Either. Both. My point is that I‚Äôm a bit of a performance snob when it comes to games, and returning to the choppy 30FPS era of the PS4 and late Xbox 360 is always painful for my eyes and never feels great. Emulation isn‚Äôt really a solution either, as PS4 emulation is currently still in its early stages and not nearly as robust as what you‚Äôll find in modern PS2 or PS3 emulators.

So it‚Äôs very helpful that Ubisoft is going back and doing the work to get its back catalog of PS4-era games, including some bangers like Far Cry 4, running at 60FPS. I mean, I don‚Äôt really need more games to add to my damn backlog, but still, thanks.
